awd_titl_txt: REU Site: Dynamic Urban Environmental Systems and Sustainability in Newark, NJ
awd_abstract_narration: A new program will be established to provide research experiences for predominantly underrepresented minority undergraduate students from urban areas in urban environmental sciences. A cohort of 12 students per year will be recruited largely from the Garden State Louis Stokes Alliance for Minority Participation and other similar programs for an 8-week summer research experience at Rutgers University in Newark and nearby field sites. Impoverished inner city areas in the United States represent the largest untapped source for human resources in STEM. This program will encourage students from this background to pursue environmental sciences by showing relevance and importance of the research to their lives and communities in terms of public health and quality of life. The students will be challenged by the dynamic complexity of the interacting environmental systems and the specter of attempting to develop ways to make such impacted systems sustainable. The goal is to transition this challenge into a desire to pursue research in it and ultimately to create a pathway for inner city youth into STEM research careers by making them of personal interest. Although students will conduct research in distinct areas of environmental geophysics, geochemistry, ecology, biogeoscience and geospatial analysis, all efforts will be interrelated for the students so they can appreciate the importance and interplay of each project. Projects will look at the geochemistry of inorganic pollutants in soils and their effect on plant growth, phosphate and other fertilizer runoff and sequestration in mineral species, the movement and natural attenuation of contaminants in shallow groundwater systems and the effect of air pollutant fallout on natural systems among others. The program will especially utilize the nearby highly impacted but now protected Hackensack Meadowlands as a unique natural laboratory for projects. The research experiences will be integrated into the student educational experiences to unify them rather than having them be stand-alone experiences. This will be done through a series of workshops which will also connect the research and educational experience to graduate education and careers. The integration of research experience, college education, graduate studies and career will form the cornerstone of the model pathway.

por.por_cntn:
The Dynamic Urban Environmental Science and Sustainability (DUESS) project was an 8-week residential research experience for undergraduates in either environmental geophysics, environmental geochemistry, atmospheric chemistry or ecology all within an urban environment. The project utilized the Garden State LSAMP and Northern New Jersey Bridges to the Baccalaureate (NNJB2B) programs as well as national REU network to recruit 75% underrepresented minority students overall. In addition to research, the groups were assembled weekly for academic enrichment in areas like careers in research, giving professional presentations, reading and writing research articles, graduate school, scholarships and fellowships, and applying for graduate research fellowship program among others. There were also interesting field trips and other more social activities to bind the group together. Students were required to construct a poster on their individual research projects and to present it to the group and any faculty and graduate students who chose to attend. The students also wrote abstracts and made videos with help of their advisors which were then submitted to the American Geophysical Union AGU) video showcase. The abstracts were published by AGU.

The innovative aspect of the project was the recruitment of 50-60% community college students in each cohort. The topical research groups included a mix of community college and 4-year students. The 4-year students were trained and encouraged to mentor the community college students in addition to the faculty mentors. The community college students were less intimidated to talk to their 4-year peers about concepts and issues that they did not understand. This arrangement greatly improved the confidence and self-efficacy of the community college students whose research ability advanced very quickly to near that of the 4-year students by the middle of the program.

The result of this experiment is that all but one community college student attended a 4-year program in STEM disciplines in good programs and many are attending graduate school. The most impressive result is that 8 students from Rutgers University attended the program over the three years. Of those, six were underrepresented minority female students. All six excelled in both academics and research through the rest of their undergraduate careers and entered graduate programs with the intention of earning a PhD. Further, all began with full fellowships at excellent programs such as Georgia Tech, University of Florida, Texas A&M, Rutgers University and University of Oklahoma and five are still in their programs and excelling.

The assessments of each cohort were stellar and improved each year by making adjustments to the program in responding to the comments. The 4-year students were especially positive about the program and expressed their pleasure in serving as mentors. Many of the Garden State LSAMP and NNJB2B students became much more active in these enrichment programs once they completed DUESS.
